drug.name: Ferric carboxymaltose
drug.description: Ferric Carboxymaltose is an iron replacement product and chemically, an iron carbohydrate complex. FDA approved on July 25, 2013.
drug.indication: Ferric carboxymaltose is a iron replacement product indicated for the treatment of iron deficiency anemia in adult patients who have intolerance to oral iron or have had unsatisfactory response to oral iron or those who have non-dialysis dependent chronic kidney disease.
drug.pharmacodynamics: When measured using positron emission tomography (PET), the red cell uptake of 59-Fe and 52-Fe from INJECTAFER ranged from 61% to 99%. In patients with iron deficiency, the red cell uptake ranged from 91% to 99%. In patients with renal anemia, the red cell uptake ranged from 61% to 84%.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Ferric carboxymaltose is a colloidal iron (III) hydroxide in complex with carboxymaltose, a carbohydrate polymer that release iron.
drug.toxicity: The most common adverse reactions (>2%) are nausea, hypertension, flushing, hypophosphatemia, and dizziness.
drug.absorption: When a single dose of 100 to 1000 mg of iron was given to iron deficient patients, the maximum serum concentration (Cmax) was 37 μg/mL to 333 μg/mL. These levels were obtained 15 minutes to 1.21 hours post dose (Tmax).
drug.route-of-elimination: Renal elimination of iron was negligible.

category.category: Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting

drug-interaction.name: Moxifloxacin
drug-interaction.description: Ferric carboxymaltose can cause a decrease in the absorption of Moxifloxacin resulting in a reduced serum concentration and potentially a decrease in efficacy.
